title: Fun and Addicting 😊
text: I have played this game ever since 2019 and it’s always been something truly special to me. Something about getting a really high score is so gratifying and it makes you feel very happy. My current score is 6 million but I guarantee I’ll be able to beat it and then beat that score and so on! Even the ads are good; like instead of other games where you are forced to watch an ad, this game rewards if you watch them! I never thought I’d actually want to watch an ad for a game but this game makes me want to because I can get rewards. in fact, you can get infinite hoverboards if you just keep watching ads! But enough about that, thank you Subway Surfers team for making this game so awesome and so fun! You deserve my 5/5 review! 👍🏻

title: Developers, please read this review if you want to improve your game (player of over 5 years)
text:
Subway Surfers is a decent endless runner game with vibrant visuals and addictive gameplay. However, it falls short in certain aspects that could greatly enhance the player experience. I’ve been playing this game for years, and unfortunately, at a certain point, it gets to be no fun. 

Hover boards, a crucial element in navigating obstacles, lack the option to fully upgrade (upgrades are specific only to the specific board you have and, say you want to use double jump on a board that has no upgrade options, you’re out of luck), limiting player control in a game that has a lot of potential. Additionally, the restriction to selecting only two power-ups at a time feels limiting; expanding to three or four would provide more strategic options. Even then, there is a lack of actually useful power ups for boards- I pretty much exclusively use double jump and super speed (because the game is so slow that it’s almost zero fun to play without a super speed board). 

The game's pay-to-win model becomes apparent in events where acquiring new characters can feel like a costly endeavor. Super mystery boxes, though rare, most often yield very underwhelming rewards, making the pursuit of the jackpot seemingly futile and is something nobody really attempts. National ranking adds a competitive edge but is marred by platform-specific limitations, detracting from its significance- users on iPhone can’t see the scores of android users, so what’s the point in being #1 nationally if it’s only for iPhone users? Even then, there is no world-wide ranking system which is ironic for a game that does a “world tour” pretty much constantly. 

Furthermore, the ceiling for increasing multipliers through missions feels prematurely capped, discouraging further engagement beyond a certain point. 

Enhancing these aspects would undoubtedly elevate the overall experience, fostering greater player satisfaction and longevity.
